110
imaginary picture, but what has taken place
in the United States, & by no very abtruse train of
reasoning will be seen in Texas. The little Farmers
about here cultivate or "raise" cotton enough for their
own uses, which the females of the family card, &
spin for clothing & with deer skins that men
make their hunting & working dresses -
15th. Started to get to L__ ? and next day to dinner were we had been regaled with
the 'Boars' flesh & Sasafras Tea x. when the
identical sort of report was again set before us. 

The heavy rains had swelled the creeks, and

at Cypress Bayou, & there being no Ferry, had
to amuse ourselves by Swimming it; It being
a hot day the dipping was a comfortable bath.

 Arrived at Houston in the Afternoon - 

On the road met the Courier or Post man, or Mail-rider*
he gave us a paper containing an account of the 
fight at Lipantitlan which I cut out and 
present to my readers.
x The Yawpon banes - to my taste make a better
Substitute for Tea.

112. 
18. I called on His Excellency the President & Congress 
is still in session - 
19. Left Houston for Galveston. here once more I
enjoyed the cool & grateful Sea-breeze. Things are
looking very flat. "Poverty is staring us in the faces,
our Imports exceed our Exports this year, our 'difficulties'
are very pressing." The Congress has not adjourned,
but all important business has been gone into. The War
bill, with its amendments by the opposition gives the President
more power than he believes judicious to exercise,
and it is supposed that he will Vitoe it, on the
grounds of unconstitutionality. So prior to this
government that the 6X per day cannot be paid to
the Members of Congress or Exchequer Bills may be
paid but they are at 70% discount. The times
will come when Members of Congress will not
requires that their expenses be paid by the Treasury.
23. General Canales, ( a base traitor to Texas x why dont he pay his debts in Galveston?) who
headed the Lepantitlan Marauders, has had
it in contemplation to form a 'Northern Mexican
Republic!  But General Arista coquett?
x This too referred to the period when Indian & many Texan
Volunteers went to arrest him

29 crossed out
30. United States Brig of War 'Dolphin' arrived bringing
news that the Santa Fe prisoners
would be liberated in a few days, on Santanas birthday
August. Variable weather. Fresh gales occasionally
from Northern & Eastern, & high tides the water coming
up into the town. The N.E. & rain winds this time of the 
year are no looked upon as healthy as blowing
from the low Swamps of Louisiana.

 The Government of the U. States appear to be getting tired

of the "Manana" & pay tomorrow systems on 
account of certain claims of some millions of dollars
and ? some reports of war destined for
Vera Cruz.

Vol III Cop: I
Through the unremitting exertions of General Hamilton Texas was recognized by England in Nov. 1840 & previously to this period the General has the honor of negociating [sic]  the treaties of recognition with France, Belgium & Holland.  It was hoped by these recognitions that Gl. H. would have been able to have negociated a Loan for Texas, but the general financial crisis & some other causes prevented this, thus Gl. H. left Europe & passing through the United States, presented himself at Austin.  The Congress was about adjourning, a New President & his administration now held power and altho Gl H had rendered important diplomatic service & his newly adopted country, his not being successful in financial matters caused his reception in Austin to be anything but flattering.   Gl. H. left Texas for Carolina to join his family from whom he had been seperated some time, with the idea of returning shortly to Texas when he should have arranged his private affairs in the States. X  
X June1842.  It is said that some [?]  took place at Austin between Gl. H. & W. K. that the Gl has sent him a challenge to England & he followed it

  France for some time past had its representative in M. Saligny as Minister, X with a French Consul in Galveston.
  Belgium sent an agent in the person of Captn Pierson to communicate with the Govt this Gentleman after visiting Austin made a journey through part of the Western country & suggested that a colony of Belgium might be established on the Rio Grande in which the Texas Gov acquiesced.  Capt P. returned to Europe to give an account of his mission.

  Early in 1842 Mr Wm Kennedy author of "The Rise Progress & Prospects"   paid Texas a second visit, to purchase lands.  The Govt conferred upon this gentleman the consul Generalship to Great Britain, & at the same time allotted him grants of land upon certain conditions (see Appendix III) to the S & W of San Antonio, upon the Rivers Frio, Leon & down to the Nueces, taken in grants upon the Rio Grande.
  The same sort of grants were made to M. Wm Castro with the Texan Consul Generals [?] to France. *   Messrs Kenedy & Castro returned to Europe to attend to these matters & who could thus intrust themselves to provide useful & hospitable colonists.

Ashbel Smith was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to France with the function of exchanging the Treaty with England, accompnd by Mr. Tenlon as  [?] of Legation.

 For some time past - it may be said for the last six years - Texas had been threatened with invasion & annihilation by Mexico.    Texas had tried but in vain by long honorable & equitable means to come to an amicable adjustment.  By Sea invasion was impossible, for Mexico has no fleets in activity, & the little but effective Texas Squadron was found sufficient to [?oppose?] Yucutan and [?] the enemys posts.

[in left margin is written Houston]

  The congress having adjourned, the President & principal members of the Govt being at Galveston  information arrived that large bodies of Mexicans had crossed the Rio Grande.  It  was officially confirmed on the 10th March that the enemy was in the country.  The excitement was very great, some supposing that a serious Mexican war was now upon the Eve of bursting forth - although Gl. Houston did not entertain this view of the subject.  Nevertheless the regular army was in motion; every citizen putting

himself in a position to dispute every inch of ground with the Enemy.  the Mexicans had advanced as far as San Antonio the tributary - Proclamation signed by General Arista, the composition of which /Appendix A/ showed how little he knew of the Texan character, supposing that they would now submit to Santana.  With this military [?] of the Enemy it was reported & credited by many, that this was the advanced guard of some 15 or 20.000 men.
[written in left margin: Houston]

  At the same time it was reported that three Mexican transports were off the coast laden with Arms & to be conveyed in a [?] to the Mexican Army.
  The Government coffers were empty, but the patriotism & munificent [?] of the Citizens of Galveston and others equipped the Steamer "Lafitte" and two small crafts to go on the coast to intercept the said transports.  This expedition was under the command of Capt. J. Wade manned by a part of the Galveston Coast Guards X - the Galveston [?] cooperating.  thus on the 14th March this expedition put to Sea.  It cruised in & about the Bays

X called the "Red Rovers" from wearing Red Shirts.

  Thus the country would be now in a comparative good state of defence & upheld although under great struggles by the patriotism and  [[?ortion?] of its citizens.
  The retur'g Austin proclamation had the effect of putting a stop of agricultural affairs in the west & many farmers left their lands, not deeming it safe to remain, but the produce of the cotton crops was not affected & some 80 to 90,000 bales were exported.   There is no doubt but it had some injury to colonization for the moment from the States & England & measurably affected commercial relations with Europe.
 Party spirit ran high against the Executive, on the part of those who had just left power - they wishing to invade Mexico instanter.  But for the object funds were requested & a large armed force, this was not practicable.
 The Texan navy returned from Yucatan having been paid some 35,000$ went to N. Orleans to refit & [?let?] in fresh Men.  Three Small Mexican vessels were taken & sent to Galveston.

116
September 14th.  At no period has the extreme political horizon of Texas looked so clear (same as regards Mexico) or its position among nations better.  Texas has been recognized by the U. States, France, England, Holland, Belgium, Rome & negotiations in this point are going on with the Hanseatic States.  From England especially when the state be at peace with Mexico - her manufacturers and Emigrants will pour in.  Although this country has passed Y is still passing through a painful ordeal, yet produce has increased & the returns of Galveston from [?] to July gives a considerable item in favor of exports.  After the Battle of St. Jacinto the majority of citizens sheathed the Sword & took to the plough.  Those many of who came form the U. States or Volunteers found it not to send them to settle down in the country returned to their homes.   Yet a Military or War party existed & when out of power, they have been accused of acts of turbulence.  The Navy of late found employment in [?] the Yacatecos.  The outs in Texas live on, & love "excitement" & this opposition partakes at times of factious violence.  When the Mexicans entered San Antonio in the Spring, the War Party was up in Arms and 'onward' was their cry.  The President discountinanced as much as he was able

21.  A Brig with a White flag at her fore & a Mexican flag at her [?] came in bringing he rest of the Santa Fe' prisoners with Genl McLeod, 10 days from Vera Cruz (14 of those liberated prisoners had died of Black Vomit at Vera Cruz).  The Brig came to anchor 3 miles below the Town.  There were some 183 or more huddled together.  I went on board, it was in the evening, they appeared like a dense sluggishly moving mass;  all severely sun burnt, & wretchedly clad.  The effluence on board was unpleasant indeed & it was reported that there was a case of black Vomit.  Captain Halliday one of those who escaped from Fannons massacre had died in the passage.  Some observed that they

[?] Meullard "Barrister at Law in Texas" somehow or another in his return to Europe after a short residence in Texas - (among his other operations was received as a Barrister) This honor he boasts in all probability has found difficult to attain in his own country.  He returns to Europe, writes his history of Texas, but not the History of the Country.  The Old Spanish proverb of "[?] con [?] ondas, yo te dire qura dio' explains at least to any enquiry from the reasons he had in emanating his work under the patronage of the Mexican Govt.  I mention here the subject of a communication by him against not very favorable to Texas, read to the Geograpical Society of London in 1840 - & by each to his mind the discipline that arose out of that production & the [?] very [?] personal report he made  to bar M. by a member of the Society.   If he has  forgotten - this may bring it back to his recollection.   I might fill pages in showing the untruths & [?] contained in his work, but refer 1st to what he says when speaking of Texas [?].  Mr. M. could never have been admitted into the Country of Texas ladies, or he would not accuse them of smoking pipes.  That Mr. M. might have seen some gude auld wife, in the back woods whiffing at a corn cob piple I will not deny - Has Mr M ever travelled in Wales, or some parts of Yorkshire, to say nothing of auld Ireland

if not I beg to inform him that I have seen Farmer's wives & others smoking their pipe in England.

  When an informer to the "Swab" I have never seen it used in Texas by ladies.  I have in the West Indies & a piece of the proper sort of wood makes an excellent apology for a tooth brush - but as to snuff being generally used - O fie on you Mr. M. none of it had been so - When in your gallantry to the sea - in a subsequent journey noticed this only once.
  Now with regard to the Hotels.  I confess that the accommodation occasionally met with is not quite so recherchê as at Fantons or [?Songs?], but in the principal towns I have been in such as Galveston, Houston, Matajorda, [?] Austin, Brozeman, Gonzales, Sn. Antonio &c &c I have been perfectly contented with the accommodation offered, & this someone during a period that was not for the moment so flourishing as when Mr. M. was in the country.   It was probably my good fate to make the acquaintance of hospitable planters rather persons in the Country & which honestly I have informed [?] my kinship.

123

 Then with regard to the the Killing of the Indians Mr. M. says 8000 perished during the Mexican & Texan Revolutions - Preposterous!  I beg to inform Mr. M. that the Mexican Revolution commenced about the year 1810 - What number of Indians were killed from that time until 1831-2 when the Texan Revolution commenced, must be subtracted at least from the 8000.  I suppose I must confess I am not sentimental enough to be ever repeating "O the Poor Indians! O the poor Red Man!  The Natural [?] of the Lost! &c &c"  But may observe that for their own sakes it is a pity they do not become agriculturally inclined - then a smaller quantity of land, would administer more rationally to their wants; industry would [?] in utilizing them.   They would no more be [?] indolent Wanderers, nor require so much territory for their hunting incursions.
  The intercourse between them and the White Man would then be what it ought to be & the Red Man in time would become a useful member of society.  At present, they are mere hunters that take advantage of them.  some of the Indian Chiefs in Texas are

124
intelligent men speaking English & Spanish & with proper Management & in time many of the Indian tribes in Texas may be released from the Savage state.   I need hardly mention how the progress towards a state of civilization the Cherokees in the U.S. are advancing.   They were doing the same in Texas, had their farms & Stock when the wars commenced & moreover the [symbol referring to marginal note:  Cherokee were found to be in communication with the enemy.] which ended at the d?k? of Bowles 'Egg"* & other Chiefs & a dispersion of the tribes  [X symbol referring to marginal note:  I may observe that of late treaties have been made with all the Indian tribes in Texas excepting the Comanches, & ere long it is expected to have a treaty with them.]

  Mr. M. says in another part that there are no roads in Texas (excepting natural ones) The Old Spaniards, Mexicans & the present occupiers of the soil have cut many roads, & at great expense,  I have travelled from Houston to Swartwout on a carriage road, east through Pine woods -  Is there not a carriage road from the Rio Grande through the whole of [symbol referring to marginal note:  Texas by Nacogdoches into the United States.]  Roads are made through forests by finding the direction by a compass from say from one Town to another - then commencing in that [?], Cutting pieces off with a axe from the Sides of Trees at that time - this is called 'Blazing" &



Chief Bowles aka 'Egg'

125
removing the intermediate trees.  I must own that the Texan forest roads would be better for sundry stumps taken away  & Macadamized.  but the roads or tracks on the Prairie in dry weather are excellent.  A friend of mine went the other day from Houston to Austin, then on to St Antonio & to the Nueces & from there to Galveston in a Buggy.  Indeed with few exceptions the greater portion of the country can be traveled in pretty direct lines by Waggons and karts or how ? the settlers move onwards -

  I have considered it a duty on my part to have made the above observations relative to the M. view of things in Texas - And in conclusion will add that we must [crossed out: have] seen through a different medium.  (If request Review Mr. Maitlands Book)

126  During the Spring assizes, it was expected that there would be a very interesting trial, namely of a woman for the murder of her husband.  The case was that the husband had given her cause to be jealous upon which in a paroxysm of jealous rage - she shot him.   The Coroners inquest found her guilty of Murder & she was incarcerated until the Assizes should open.*    Judge Morriss opened the court - then followed the entry of Mexicans into San Antonio, the Judge, gentlemen of the bar & the principal officers of Court were off to the Army - the Woman who was about to be tried for Murder, was bailed - she went up the country to her friends - & in all probability when called upon would be 'Non inventus.'

   The following occurred in Galveston lately - A ? one whose brother had been hung for murder in the ? & he himself had the ? X  What record of a fellow was beating his wife early one morning.  An industrious citizen was passing by on the way to his Store, when the woman cried out for help to him as he was passing by requesting him to go for the Sheriff.   The husband immediately ran out, plunged a Knife into the individual passing, some neighbors rescued him - a Surgeon was sent for and dressed his

Reserrection. - We understand that a Mr. Haskins, of Galveston, was taken suddenly sick a day or two since, and died, as was supposed by his friends, with the yellow fever.  He was regularly laid out, leads placed  on his eyes, &c., and a short time after he came rushing down stairs almost frightened out of his wits, declaring that there was a ghost in his room.  He is now rapidly recovering and will probably be well in a few days.   - Telegraph

 Another news we get from Mexico comes trumpeting that by sea & land we may momentarily expect to be invaded.
  Should this "consumation devoutly to be wished' come off - By land the Texans are ready for the enemy - Galveston island is getting into a State of defense under Col. Hockly, & the Volunteers of the City.   Nature has been kind enough to form natural trenches, on the Sea Shore of Sand, from behind these should an enemy land there would be at least without any enforcements 600 [?Rifles?] ready to welcome them, and no want of Artillery -
     Santa Ana must have sufficient to employ himself just now - the capital to keep in military order - political & military discontents to coquette with.   The United States claims - the disobedience of Yucatan & Texas to chastise & lastly the ambiguous tenure by which he holds his Dictatorial position.   [?] the late military promenade, increased in carrying away some defenseless inhabitants from San Antonio - In this he was assisted by the Traitor Saguin, this last having been personally concerned in butchering Dawsons Company of Lafayette Volunteers.  With [?] pushing on to the Colorado, with hope of crossing that stream, then marching upon Austin sacking it & burning the Archives - but he was afraid to cross the Colorado for many coûtes and coûtes & for fear of being hemmed in by the Texans

18th   The last Congress offered the  President almost dictatorial powers - he veto'd the bill to that effect as unconstitutional.  Some went so far to say that the Congress wished to  commit him. He remained in Houston some time, oftimes personally suffering in his finances.

  The President then for reasons best known to himself, removed the Seat of Govt to Washington on the Brazos & went there with his Lady.   The Secretary of War and Marine Col. Hackly resigned, emptying the Command at Galveston.  The President it is reported has it in contemplation, finding that the Volunteer Chiefs will not obey him to organize a standing army of 5000 men.  the cost of pulling  this number in the field will be 250,000$ & the 150,000 per annum, the private soldier pay being at 8$ per month.
 The following on the particulars of the top of the 'Merchant' Steamer from N. Orleans to Galveston.

November.  Many persons having families are leaving Galveston, fearing that Galveston may be attacked.  
7th  Letters arrived from Belasco at night-fall saying that a Fleet of vessels with Steamers in Company was supposed to have been seen off that port.  All the Volunteers obeyed the Tocsin, which was rung at the Presbyterian  Church - The different companies formed under their respective officers & the greater part of them occupied all night in getting Col. Hackleys boat on the East end of the island in order in case there should be any truth in the report.  Anxiously we watched the mornings dawn of the 8th  I accompanied                [?Sumpter?] the Pilot to the Beacon, he climbed to the top, waited then until it was broad day light - But no signs of the enemy.
11th  The 'New York' Steamer brought us news that the Steamer fleet composed of 10 Sail had left Vera Cruz for Yucatan, with promissas to come to Galveston after the rebel Yucatans are brought to their duty.   The Texan Squadron are there at N. Orleans & without the means to get to Sea.  The Summer had left us & it is getting cold.   N.W. Gales set in, now we have the commencement of winter.

  The British Government has ordered home all the British officers & Seamen now in the Mexican Service - this act is a [?] gain for Texas.

27th  The Mexican Government talking of seating certain claims of the United States Government, so as to keep the Yankees quiet.  Santa Ana was at his Hacienda

March 20th.  Under this date I find amongst my notes an extract from an official communication from the Texan Minister to the Government of the United States, when speaking of the failure of entering into a communal treaty with the United States X
[note in margin:]  X that the treaty had failed - Slander has performed its office!  its work is complete."  This is attributed to the "War Party".
The result is that the Texan government has put an additional duty ad valorem of five per cent on all goods imported in foreign [?bottoms?] with the exception of those foreign vessels which by treaty or act of Congress are permitted to enter a payment of the domestic duty"

  Thus Texas having no Commercial Treaty with the United States is now obliged to pay five per cent more duty than England, France, Belgium, Holland & the Hanseatic States.  Moreover the tonnage dues on the Steamers from New Orleans was increased.

element_texts.text: Completed

Indians Suing for Peace.  The President has received a message from James Logan, Agent for the Creek Indians in Arkansas, conveying the pleasing intelligence that at the late meeting of the tribes  called together in the Creek nation by Roly McIntosh, to establish amicable relations with each other, several chiefs from Texas attended.  Among these were Now-no-hitch-tow-e, head chief of the Kenchies, Ki-ki-see-no-hah, chief of a tribe residing on the Wichita, and Sar-powe-e, head chief of the Towaccanies. - They stated that they were all desirous to make peace with the Texians; and that several of the prairie tribes of Texas, including the Commanches, were also anxious for peace.  They stated that they had been at war with the Texians for several years, and were tired of hostilities, and would long since have sent in a flag of truce to our settlers, but were fearful that they would be shot down.  Mr. Logan further states, that they desire that Gen. Houston should designate a time and place to meet them, to form a treaty of peace. - They say that all the tribes of Texas, except a few renegade Cherokees, will send deputies to meet him at any place on the frontier that he may designate, and tey think all the tribes residing on our borders, will readily join in concluding the treat. - [Telegraph.

Santanas proposition for an Armistice or peace ! -
Under 26th March [?] obs. is found on Texan fleet & its operation at leaving New Orleans for Yucatan.
